H0.text: The Moon has a thinner atmosphere than Earth is the best explanation of why the Moon revolves around Earth.

H1.text: The Moon is too large to move away from Earth is the best explanation of why the Moon revolves around Earth.

H2.text: The Moon is attracted by the gravity of Earth is the best explanation for why the Moon revolves around Earth.

H3.text: The Moon has a smaller gravitational force than Earth is the best explanation of why the Moon revolves around Earth.

A4.text: The strongest gravitational pull on the Moon is towards the Sun, more than twice that towards Earth.

A5.text: The Moon's trajectory is always convex (as seen when looking Sunward at the entire Sun–Earth–Moon system from a great distance outside Earth–Moon solar orbit), and is nowhere concave (from the same perspective) or looped.

A6.text: For lunar orbits with altitudes in the 500 to 20,000 km (310 to 12,430 mi) range, the gravity of Earth leads to orbit perturbations.

A7.text: the gravity of Earth intervenes enough to make lunar orbits unstable at a distance of 690 km (430 mi).
